items.title: [Boing Boing] California is completely drought-free for the first time in 25 years
items.content_html:
For the first time since December 2000, not a single square mile of California is classified as dry on the U.S. Drought Monitor. The last time the state reached this threshold was 25 years ago, the LA Times reports.

A series of powerful winter storms and atmospheric rivers swept across the state starting in October, right on schedule â€” unlike last year. — Read the rest

The post California is completely drought-free for the first time in 25 years appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [Boing Boing] Ireland wants to give police spyware and facial recognition powers
items.content_html:
Ireland is introducing the Communications (Interception and Lawful Access) Bill to modernize its 1993 surveillance laws. The bill would let police intercept all forms of communication, including encrypted messages, deploy spyware with judicial approval, scan electronic devices, and use IMSI catchers to identify suspects, The Register reports. — Read the rest

The post Ireland wants to give police spyware and facial recognition powers appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [Metafilter] We now know that Mary Lewis was a formidable person
items.content_html: Sometimes, forgotten information about important historical figures and their connections turns up in surprising places. A little-known essay by William Dean Howells (1837-1920) is one of those places. Howells, a white writer later known as the Dean of American Letters, published "Mrs. Johnson" in The Atlantic in 1868 [PDF]. "Mrs. Johnson" was the pseudonym Howells gave to his family's Black housekeeper, Mary Lewis (1816-1868), whom he called "a subject of unique interest." But it seems neither Howells nor his wife fully understood just how uniquely interesting Mary Lewis was. from A Subject of Unique Interest: Mary Freeman Heuston Lewis and William Dean Howells [Commonplace]
items.summary: Sometimes, forgotten information about important historical figures and their connections turns up in surprising places. A little-known essay by William Dean Howells (1837-1920) is one of those places. Howells, a white writer later known as the Dean of American Letters, published "Mrs. Johnson" in The Atlantic in 1868 [PDF]. "Mrs. Johnson" was the pseudonym Howells gave to his family's Black housekeeper, Mary Lewis (1816-1868), whom he called "a subject of unique interest." But it seems neither Howells nor his wife fully understood just how uniquely interesting Mary Lewis was. from A Subject of Unique Interest: Mary Freeman Heuston Lewis and William Dean Howells [Commonplace]

_source.original_title: We now know that Mary Lewis was a formidable person

items.title: [The Guardian â€“ Global Development] â€˜We need change, not just as young people but as a countryâ€™: Ugandaâ€™s youth on 40 years of Museveni
items.content_html:
This month the president was reelected for his seventh term, devastating the hopes of many who fear a future of stagnation and unemployment

When Ugandaâ€™s electoral commission declared President Yoweri Museveni the winner of the 2026 general election this month, there was little surprise among the countryâ€™s younger voters. Those aged under 35 make up more than three-quarters (78%) of Ugandaâ€™s population â€“ the second youngest population in the world â€“ and for many, the news of Museveniâ€™s victory confirmed what they had expected. For some, it also crushed the fragile hope inspired by the rise of the opposition leader, Robert Kyagulanyi, known as Bobi Wine.

Sarah Namubiru, 21, a university student hoping to be a teacher, says she did not vote for Museveni because of the low salaries in the teaching profession.

Continue reading...
